ygData.msgSnippet: Mike, I d guess there are others in the group with similar questions so I think it s probably useful to the group. (By the way, by Adaptive Networks, I

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=_i9a7Wp2LzCj93AN4Dp0jO7XgaGQncm-pRyy3TZVsQM9AWiRttPw

Mike,

I'd guess there are others in the group with similar questions so I
=
think it's probably useful to the group. (By the way, by "Adaptive
Networks=
," I assume you are referring to adaptive neural networks?)

In any case, a=
nother option is the University of Texas at Austin,
which is where I did my=
 Ph.D. under Prof. Risto Miikkulainen, who has
a leading group in the area:=


http://nn.cs.utexas.edu

Another good lab is Prof. Jordan Pollack's DEMO =
Lab at Brandeis:

http://www.demo.cs.brandeis.edu/
http://www.cs.brandeis.e=
du/~pollack/

However, Jordan tells me that he will be renaming and revampi=
ng his
lab soon, so it will no longer be called "DEMO."  However, it is
und=
oubtedly still a good place to be.

There are some newer places too with gr=
oups led by new professors,
including Prof. Bobby Bryant's "Neuroevolution =
and Behavior
Laboratory" at the University of Nevada at Reno
(http://nebl.c=
se.unr.edu/) and Prof. Josh Bongard's new group at the
University of Vermon=
t (http://www.cs.uvm.edu/~jbongard/).

Prof. Hod Lipson at Cornell formerly=
 worked with Prof. Pollack and
runs the Cornell Computational Synthesis Lab=
:

http://ccsl.mae.cornell.edu/

However, that lab is a focused on emergent=
 phenomena in general, with
a broader scope than some of the others.

One o=
ther important group is Prof. Dario Floreano's Laboratory of
Intelligent Sy=
stems.  This lab is in Switzerland, so I am not sure if
it conducts its day=
-to-day work in English (it might), but in any case
it is very prominent in=
 the area:

http://lis.epfl.ch/

Not all these groups have an explicit focu=
s on neural networks, but
most have done some good work with them.

Note th=
at any Ph.D. program in North America should be willing to
support you fina=
ncially if you get in.  

ken
 



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "frayn.mich=
ael" <frayn.michael@...> wrote:
>
> Hello everyone,
> 
> I am about to head=
 over to the University of Sussex (in Brighton,
> England) to do their MSc =
in Evolutionary & Adaptive Systems.
> 
> However, as I am Canadian, the con=
cept of doing a PhD there is a
> little daunting because of the cost. Unfor=
tunately, I am not aware of
> many other Universities that would be interes=
ted in funding a PhD of
> such research focuses (let alone would be able to=
 comprehensively
> support students along the way). This assumes, of course=
, that my MSc
> is wildly successful and I come up with a research question=
 worthy of
> funding.
> 
> Anyhow, I was hoping that some of the members he=
re might be able to
> point out other Universities (in North America or Eng=
lish-speaking
> Europe) that may be appropriate to do such a PhD in. These =
are the
> ones I'm familiar with now:
> 
> University of Edinburgh
> Univer=
sity of Sussex
> University of Central Florida
> 
> I realize this isn't di=
rectly related to NEAT but I couldn't think of
> a more knowledgeable group=
 on the subject matter a hand. If there is a
> more appropriate group, then=
 please just point me in the right
> direction and I'll not post about this=
 again here. Apologies if it's
> too off-topic.
> 
> Cheers,
> Mike
>
